questiontext.text:
Which one of the following does NOT apply to sets?

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

[[ if test="member(1, ta_index)" ]]

The correct answer is Independence

Independence is a concept that is often associated with events or random variables, rather than sets.

[[/ if ]] [[ if test="member(2, ta_index)" ]]

The correct answer is Substitution property

Substitution property is not typically associated with set theory. It's more commonly used in logic and algebra.

[[/ if ]] [[ if test="member(3, ta_index)" ]]

The correct answer is Inverse elements

The concept of inverse elements typically applies to algebraic structures, particularly groups.

[[/ if ]] [[ if test="member(4, ta_index)" ]]

The correct answer is Identity property

This property is mostly used in algebraic structure, it refers to an element that, when combined with another element using a certain operation, leaves the other element unchanged.

[[/ if ]]

questionnote.text:
Which one of the following does NOT apply to sets?

{@ta@}

[[ if test="member(1, ta_index)" ]]

Independence

[[/ if ]] [[ if test="member(2, ta_index)" ]]

Substitution property.

[[/ if ]] [[ if test="member(3, ta_index)" ]]

Inverse elements

[[/ if ]] [[ if test="member(4, ta_index)" ]]

Identity property

[[/ if ]]
